"Heath, Joseph" wrote:

> > Then I'll leave you with this final thought:  If we design
> > software by writing tests first, do the tests document the
> > intention of the software, or its implementation?
> >
>
> But this assumes that our tests cover all possibilities of use, which can
> result in large test suites. I am not against this (in fact I prefer it),
> but often a few words of English (or whatever language you read) is
> preferrable (IMHO) to a large test suite.
> I still have the test suite, however, for refactoring and code proof.
>

If we don't write new code until we have a failing test, then the tests cover all the methods.  I agree that they may not test all possible parameters.  We'll maximize the testing investment by testing interesting boundary conditions and reasonable ranges for parameters.  Our code coverage will still be very high.  And yes, we'll amass test suites quickly as our tests become more comprehensive over time.

If a few words of English is necessary over and above the method signature, then by all means add it to the documentation.

>
> I would still say that that the tests document examples of the intention,
> rather than the intention itself. These examples may be a complete set or
> may not be, often just the critical subset.
>

Agreed.  Examples of intention and intention draw closer together the more we use test-first design.  Nevertheless, we're documenting intention rather than implementation.

Good points - thanks!

Mike
